articles.headline: Do Latino Voters Really Care if the 2020 Candidates Speak Spanish?
articles.snippet: They might not, according to polls, but that isn’t stopping Beto O’Rourke, Cory Booker and others.
articles.abstract: They might not, according to polls, but that isn’t stopping Beto O’Rourke, Cory Booker and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In his months on the campaign trail, Beto O’Rourke has wanted to make one thing explicitly clear: He is not a pendejo.

articles.headline: Trump Considering an Executive Order to Allow Citizenship Question on Census
articles.snippet: Justice Department lawyers also told a judge on Friday that they would press ahead with efforts to add the question, did not know yet what kind of rationale they would put forward.
articles.abstract: Justice Department lawyers also told a judge on Friday that they would press ahead with efforts to add the question, did not know yet what kind of rationale they would put forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Department lawyers told a federal judge on Friday that they would press ahead in their efforts to add a citizenship question to the 2020 census, but indicated they did not know yet what kind of rationale they would put forward.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Mad Magazine, Irreverent Baby Boomer Humor Bible, Is All but Dead
articles.snippet: After two more issues of new stuff, “the usual gang of idiots” will mainly publish old material in future issues.
articles.abstract: After two more issues of new stuff, “the usual gang of idiots” will mainly publish old material in future issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alfred E. Neuman finally has a reason to worry.

articles.headline: In Sudan, a Power-Sharing Deal Propelled by a Secret Meeting and Public Rage
articles.snippet: Just a month ago, Sudan’s protest movement appeared crippled. What led the military to suddenly agree to share power? Back-room negotiations, raw street power and a diplomatic shift by Saudi Arabia.
articles.abstract: Just a month ago, Sudan’s protest movement appeared crippled. What led the military to suddenly agree to share power? Back-room negotiations, raw street power and a diplomatic shift by Saudi Arabia.
articles.lead_paragraph: A month ago Sudan’s pro-democracy movement was battered and in disarray. Protesters were in hiding after paramilitary troops rampaged through the main protest area, looting, raping and shooting dead scores of people. The internet had been shut down. Bodies were being dredged from the Nile.

articles.headline: When ‘Black Lives Matter’ Is Invoked in the Abortion Debate
articles.snippet: For some black ministers, abortion is both wrong and understandable. “I cannot guilt her,” one pastor said of his discussions with black women considering ending their pregnancies.
articles.abstract: For some black ministers, abortion is both wrong and understandable. “I cannot guilt her,” one pastor said of his discussions with black women considering ending their pregnancies.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — As a pastor, Clinton Stancil counsels his black congregants that abortion is akin to the taking of innocent life. But as a civil rights activist, Mr. Stancil urges them to understand the social forces that prompt black women to have abortions at disproportionately high rates.

articles.headline: Europe Built a System to Fight Russian Meddling. It’s Struggling.
articles.snippet: As governments debate the best way to combat Kremlin propaganda, internal documents show the political disputes behind what appeared to be an ambitious effort.
articles.abstract: As governments debate the best way to combat Kremlin propaganda, internal documents show the political disputes behind what appeared to be an ambitious effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union launched an ambitious effort earlier this year to combat election interference: an early-warning system that would sound alarms about Russian propaganda. Despite high expectations, however, records show that the system has become a repository for a mishmash of information, produced no alerts and is already at risk of becoming defunct.

articles.headline: Outsider or Insider? How Bernie Sanders Learned to Walk the Line
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders was met with scorn when he arrived on Capitol Hill in 1990. But in the years since, he has evolved from a gadfly to a reliable team player.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders was met with scorn when he arrived on Capitol Hill in 1990. But in the years since, he has evolved from a gadfly to a reliable team player.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bernie Sanders was elected to the House in 1990 after branding himself an outsider and defying calls to join a Democratic Party he had long bashed as “ideologically bankrupt.”

articles.headline: Southern California Earthquake Rattles a State Wary of the ‘Big One’
articles.snippet: For the second time in two days, a powerful earthquake struck Southern California on Friday night, shaking a large area already on edge.
articles.abstract: For the second time in two days, a powerful earthquake struck Southern California on Friday night, shaking a large area already on edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the bottom of the fourth inning, Dodger Stadium swayed. Rides at Disneyland were evacuated, and so were movie theaters in Los Angeles. Near Palm Springs, pools sloshed and chandeliers at a casino rocked. And in the Mojave Desert town of Ridgecrest, Calif., fires roared, power went out and grocery store shelves came crashing down.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Hungry, Scared and Sick: Inside the Migrant Detention Center in Clint, Tex.
articles.snippet: An out-of-the-way border station in the desert outside of El Paso has become the epicenter of outrage over the Trump administration’s policies on the southwest border.
articles.abstract: An out-of-the-way border station in the desert outside of El Paso has become the epicenter of outrage over the Trump administration’s policies on the southwest border.
articles.lead_paragraph: An out-of-the-way border station in the desert outside of El Paso has become the epicenter of outrage over the Trump administration’s policies on the southwest border.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Manny Fernandez, Daniel Borunda, Aaron Montes and Caitlin Dickerson

articles.headline: An Online Preschool Closes a Gap but Exposes Another
articles.snippet: It is not a program for children of the rich. It is geared to lower-income families who have fewer prekindergarten options.
articles.abstract: It is not a program for children of the rich. It is geared to lower-income families who have fewer prekindergarten options.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOWLER, Calif. — David Cardenas, a mechanic and the mayor of Fowler, knows families in his town want high-quality and free daylong preschool.

articles.headline: A Political Murder and Far-Right Terrorism: Germany’s New Hateful Reality
articles.snippet: The assassination of a local politician is raising tough questions about the country’s resolve to monitor and control far-right violence.
articles.abstract: The assassination of a local politician is raising tough questions about the country’s resolve to monitor and control far-right violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The death threats started in 2015, when Walter Lübcke defended the refugee policy of Chancellor Angela Merkel. A regional politician for her conservative party, he would go to small towns in his district and explain that welcoming those in need was a matter of German and Christian values.

articles.headline: Warren and Harris Rise in Democratic Primary, Challenging Male Front-Runners
articles.snippet: Elizabeth Warren and Kamala Harris have surged since the debate, reframing a race that Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders once hoped to control.
articles.abstract: Elizabeth Warren and Kamala Harris have surged since the debate, reframing a race that Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders once hoped to control.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — When Beth Krerowicz began reviewing the platoon of Democratic presidential candidates, her first instinct was to back Joseph R. Biden Jr., whom she saw as the strongest opponent to President Trump.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Iran Announces New Breach of Nuclear Deal Limits and Threatens Further Violations
articles.snippet: The deputy foreign minister said Iran would take additional steps over the limits on uranium enrichment in the accord unless it gets sanctions relief.
articles.abstract: The deputy foreign minister said Iran would take additional steps over the limits on uranium enrichment in the accord unless it gets sanctions relief.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iran said on Sunday that within hours it would breach the limits on uranium enrichment set four years ago in an accord with the United States and other international powers that was designed to keep Tehran from producing a nuclear weapon.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank Scales Back Ambitions, Announcing Job Cuts and Reorganization
articles.snippet: The bank that once symbolized German economic prowess is effectively abandoning hope of playing in the same league as Wall Street banks, and struggling to remain relevant.
articles.abstract: The bank that once symbolized German economic prowess is effectively abandoning hope of playing in the same league as Wall Street banks, and struggling to remain relevant.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank embarked Sunday on what may be its last chance to reverse a decade of decline, announcing that it would cut a fifth of its work force and slash operations in New York and London.

articles.headline: The ‘Texas Miracle’ Missed Most of Texas
articles.snippet: Cities outside of Austin, Dallas and other “superstars” are still waiting for their share of the state’s boom in jobs and businesses.
articles.abstract: Cities outside of Austin, Dallas and other “superstars” are still waiting for their share of the state’s boom in jobs and businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONGVIEW, Tex. — On the eastern plains of Texas, local leaders are trying to stop the bleeding of talent to the bright lights of Dallas and Austin. They are sprucing up downtown, completing 10 miles of walking trails, investing in parks and schools and making other improvements that they hope will entice young workers to stay and help this part of the state finally claim a share of the Texas Miracle.

articles.headline: Florida’s Utilities Keep Homeowners From Making the Most of Solar Power
articles.snippet: The political clout and incentives of the state’s big power companies have discouraged installation of rooftop solar panels.
articles.abstract: The political clout and incentives of the state’s big power companies have discouraged installation of rooftop solar panels.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Florida calls itself the Sunshine State. But when it comes to the use of solar power, it trails 19 states, including not-so-sunny Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York and Maryland.

articles.headline: Big Tech ‘Knows You Better Than Your Wife.’ He Plans to Rein It In.
articles.snippet: Germany’s top antitrust official is urging other countries to take on Facebook and its peers by attacking what the companies value most: data.
articles.abstract: Germany’s top antitrust official is urging other countries to take on Facebook and its peers by attacking what the companies value most: data.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Germany’s top antitrust enforcer, Andreas Mundt, recently asked a room full of lawyers, academics and regulators to imagine a wall filled with their personal information collected by Facebook and Google. He told them to picture it stocked with their data broken up into categories like finances, location, relationships and hobbies.

articles.headline: James Monroe Enslaved Hundreds. Their Descendants Still Live Next Door.
articles.snippet: A small African-American community has existed less than 10 miles from the president’s former plantation for generations. Only recently has the full extent of their relationship been revealed.
articles.abstract: A small African-American community has existed less than 10 miles from the president’s former plantation for generations. Only recently has the full extent of their relationship been revealed.
articles.lead_paragraph: [For more coverage of race, sign up here to have our Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch and Miranda Barnes

articles.headline: Employee Activism Is Alive in Tech. It Stops Short of Organizing Unions.
articles.snippet: Efforts to form unions at several smaller tech companies have stalled, showing the limits of how far a wave of employee activism can go.
articles.abstract: Efforts to form unions at several smaller tech companies have stalled, showing the limits of how far a wave of employee activism can go.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In February, about a dozen employees at a small technology company called NPM embarked on an effort that is often frowned upon at start-ups: trying to unionize.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: As the World Heats Up, the Climate for News Is Changing, Too
articles.snippet: Rival newsrooms are joining together to meet a crisis years in the making. But there is disagreement among some journalists on how to play the story.
articles.abstract: Rival newsrooms are joining together to meet a crisis years in the making. But there is disagreement among some journalists on how to play the story.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Europe heats up, Greenland melts and the Midwest floods, many news organizations are devoting more resources to climate change as they cover the topic with more urgency.

articles.headline: Turkey’s Long, Painful Economic Crisis Grinds On
articles.snippet: Turkey remains stuck in perilous proximity to economic crisis, as households and businesses defer spending and investment in the face of weak growth.
articles.abstract: Turkey remains stuck in perilous proximity to economic crisis, as households and businesses defer spending and investment in the face of weak growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARHAVI, Turkey — The terraced rows of tea plants climbing the hills above the Black Sea used to glint like money. Lately, they look like another casualty of Turkey’s long, grinding economic crisis.
